overview: How and when to apply for planning permission, what documents to submit, how to appeal and how to comment on other people's planning applications
title: Planning permission

table.body:
You'll need planning permission from your local planning authority (LPA) if you want to develop land or buildings.

Your LPA is usually your local council. In national parks the LPA is the national park authority.

^[Find your LPA](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/wps/portal/genpub_LocalInformation?docRef=LocalInformation&scope=202&langid=0 "Planning Portal: find your local planning authority"){:rel="external"} on the Planning Portal website.^

You may need planning permission for:

+ constructing or changing buildings
+ changing the use of land or buildings
+ demolishing some buildings

The LPA can either:

+ give you planning permission (possibly with conditions)
+ [turn you down](if-your-applications-turned-down "Planning permission: your application's turned down")
 
*[LPA]: local planning authority
table.title: Overview

table.body:
It’s your responsibility to check with [your local planning authority (LPA)](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/wps/portal/genpub_LocalInformation?docRef=LocalInformation&scope=202&langid=0 "Planning Portal: find your local planning authority"){:rel="external"} if you need planning permission before you start any development.

^The [interactive house](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/permission/house "Planning Portal: interactive house"){:rel="external"} shows you what planning permission you may need for different projects around your home.^

Smaller building works don't usually need planning permission, as long as you meet certain conditions. These smaller projects include:

+ extensions
+ conservatories
+ loft conversions
+ sheds 

These are called ‘permitted developments’. Some LPAs may **not** allow this, though, in which case you still need to apply for planning permission.

You might **not** have permitted development rights if you live in:

+ a listed building 
+ a conservation area
+ a national park
+ an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty
+ the Norfolk or Suffolk Broads

^Find out more about [permitted developments]( http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/permission/responsibilities/planningpermission/permitted "Planning Portal: permitted development"){:rel="external"} on the Planning Portal website.^

*[LPAs]: local planning authorities 
*[LPA]: local planning authority
table.title: Do you need planning permission?

table.body:
##Apply online
You can [apply for planning permission online](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/applications/planningapplications "Planning Portal: apply online"){:rel="external"} through the Planning Portal website. This sends your application to your local planning authority (LPA).

##Apply on paper
You can [download planning application forms](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/PpApplications/genpub/en/Ecabinet "Planning Portal: apply on paper"){:rel="external"} from the Planning Portal website to send to your LPA.

^Get more [advice on how to apply](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/applications/howtoapply/ "Planning Portal: learn how to apply"){:rel="external"} on the Planning Portal website.^

##What to submit
Different LPAs can ask you for different [documents to support your application.](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/applications/howtoapply/whattosubmit/ "Planning Portal: what to submit"){:rel="external"} However, you always need:

+ a site location plan (showing the proposed development in relation to surrounding properties)
+ a block plan (showing the proposed development in relation to the property boundary)

^Planning officers at your local council can check if you have all the documents you need to apply. Some councils charge for this service.^

##Application fee
You have to pay a fee for most planning applications. The amount depends on your application. 

You can use an online calculator to work out fees in [England](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/PpApplications/genpub/en/StandaloneFeeCalculator "Planning portal: fee calculator for England"){:rel="external"} and [Wales.](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/PpApplications/genpub/en/StandaloneFeeCalculator?isWelsh=true "Planning portal: fee calculator for Wales"){:rel="external"}

##Who to tell
If you’re not the sole owner of your property, you must tell the other part owner. 

If the property is leasehold, you must tell any leaseholders with at least 7 years left on their lease.

##Letting someone else handle your application
If you don’t want to handle the application yourself, you can ask your agent, architect, solicitor or builder to do it for you.

*[LPAs]: local planning authorities
*[LPA]: local planning authority
table.title: How to apply

table.body:
s1. The Planning Portal sends your application to the local planning authority (LPA).  
s2. The LPA checks your application and makes it public to let other people comment on it.  
s3. The LPA approves or [refuses](if-your-applications-turned-down "Planning permission: your application's turned down") your application.  

%Only start your building work after the LPA tells you that you have planning permission.%

The LPA will try to decide your application within 8 weeks. If it needs longer, it will usually write to you and ask for an extension. This might happen if your building project is complex or affects lots of people. 

^Find out more about the [decision-making process](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/applications/decisionmaking/ "Planning Portal: decision-making"){:rel="external"} on the Planning Portal website.^

*[LPA]: local planning authority
table.title: What happens to your application
Your application’s turned down

table.body:
All building projects that need planning permission must be made public. You can look at the plans and comment on them. 

The local planning authority (LPA) will post notices near the building site and/or write letters to people who live nearby to ask if they agree with the plans.

For large projects, like a school or supermarket, the LPA will also put a notice in the local newspaper.

%You’ll need to look at the plans and make comments before the deadline set by the LPA.%

You can also go to council meetings about the development. You can speak in these meetings but you can’t vote on the planning application.

Once the LPA has given planning permission for a new development, you can’t change the permission.

*[LPA]: local planning authority
table.title: Commenting on planning applications
